Character Description: Entities that set and enforce policies or standards related to food safety, agriculture, labor, or environmental practices, such as the USDA or state food inspection agencies.
Organizations or companies that provide digital tools, platforms, or infrastructure to support food tracking, distribution, logistics, or agricultural efficiency.
Groups or individuals that share information and raise awareness about food issues, policies, and services, including journalists, advocacy organizations, or public information offices.
Elected officials or governing bodies that create and pass laws influencing the food system, such as city councils, state legislatures, or Congress.
Agencies responsible for protecting community health through nutrition guidance, food safety monitoring, and disease prevention, like local health departments or the CDC.
Grassroots or local organizations that work directly with residents to provide food access, education, or support, often targeting underserved communities.
Private foundations or charitable institutions that fund food access, education, and system reform efforts through grants or donations.
Organizations or agencies that distribute funds to support food system projects, such as public health initiatives, urban farms, or food recovery programs.
Farms or gardens within city environments that grow produce for local consumption, education, or economic development.
Companies or municipal services that collect, treat, or dispose of food waste and related materials, aiming to reduce environmental impact.
Collaborative groups connecting producers, distributors, and consumers to support localized, equitable food systems.
Public sector bodies at local, state, or federal levels that influence food policy, funding, infrastructure, and oversight.
Operators that don't fall neatly into traditional categories but influence the food system, such as food media, influencers, or unregistered mutual aid groups.
Locally focused farms that prioritize community involvement, education, and access over profit, often using sustainable practices.
Large-scale farms operated by entities like prisons, universities, or military bases to supply food for internal use.
Small-scale growing spaces managed by residents or volunteers, often for personal or shared consumption and community engagement.
Privately owned farms that operate for profit, often producing high volumes of crops or livestock for sale through wholesalers or retailers.
Farms specializing in raising animals for meat, dairy, or egg production, ranging from small pastures to industrial operations.
Businesses that produce baked goods such as bread, pastries, and cakes for local sale, wholesale, or retail distribution.
Facilities that receive raw milk and process it into consumable products like cheese, yogurt, and butter for distribution.
Facilities that prepare and sell meat products, often sourcing from farms or processors for local distribution.
Industrial facilities where raw agricultural products are transformed into finished food goods or ingredients, such as canned vegetables or frozen meals.
Operators that transport food across the system, taking food from business to business primarily. This typically is from a farm directly to an aggregator, a distributor, or processor.
Comments: Operators who move food across the supply chain, from farms to processors, retailers, and consumers, ensuring timely and safe delivery.

Character Description: Retail outlets offering a wide range of food products, typically serving neighborhoods or small communities with daily needs.

Character Description: Large-scale retail stores with extensive food selections, often part of a chain, serving urban and suburban areas.
Membership-based retail stores offering bulk food items at lower prices, typically serving families or small businesses.
Small retail outlets offering packaged foods, snacks, and beverages, often in urban or high-traffic areas with extended hours.
Organizations that collect, store, and redistribute donated or surplus food to nonprofits, pantries, and individuals in need.
Businesses that purchase large quantities of food from producers or processors and sell to retailers, institutions, or other distributors.
Establishments that prepare and serve meals directly to consumers, often sourcing ingredients from various parts of the supply chain.
Schools and universities that serve food to students and staff, often through cafeterias or food service contracts.
Hospitals and clinics that provide meals tailored to patients’ health needs, sourcing from specialized vendors or food service providers.
Local distribution centers that provide groceries or meals directly to individuals and families facing food insecurity.
Large employers or campuses that manage food service operations for their employees, often contracting external providers.
Services responsible for collecting food waste and transporting it to landfills, composting facilities, or other treatment centers.
Operators that convert organic food waste into nutrient-rich soil or compost products, supporting circular agricultural practices.

Sells prepared meals, snacks, and beverages directly to passengers through in-flight services or airport concessions. They manage large-scale food sourcing and delivery, ensuring timely, safe, and consistent service to end-consumers.

Consultants in the Dallas food system act as strategic advisors and connectors, helping align the efforts of government, nonprofit, and private sector stakeholders. They provide research, planning, and facilitation support to advance food equity, infrastructure, and policy. By bridging organizational silos, they help drive coordinated, system-wide change.

Linking community members with food resources through partnerships with nonprofits and service agencies. Can provide space, volunteers, or funding for food pantries, community meals, or educational programs. Their trusted presence in the community makes them effective at bridging gaps and coordinating local support.
An organization that redistributes food that can be repurposed for other composting or consumption purposes.

A Food Service Provider prepares and manages meals for institutions like schools, hospitals, and businesses. They deliver large-scale dining and catering services, ensuring reliable meal access in various settings.
An operator that primarily delivers food to a consumer or preparer. This could include restaurant to consumer (eg. UberEats or Doordash), or distributor to consumer.
Anyone who eats! The general consumers of Dallas represent a diverse and growing population whose food choices reflect the city’s cultural mix.
